title: How to File a Rate Complaint with the STB
excerpt: The Surface Transportation Board provides shippers a formal path to challenge railroad rates they believe exceed a reasonable maximum. Understanding the complaint process, its costs, and the evidentiary standards involved is essential before committing to litigation.

sections.heading: Overview of the STB's Role
sections.content:
The Surface Transportation Board is an independent federal agency with jurisdiction over interstate railroad transportation. It inherited its rate-reasonableness authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission when the ICC Termination Act of 1995 dissolved that body. Today the STB adjudicates disputes between shippers and rail carriers, sets standards for maximum reasonable rates, and oversees mergers, line sales, and abandonments.

The STB's authority over rates applies specifically to traffic that moves under a common-carrier obligation—meaning the railroad is legally required to offer service and the shipment is not governed by a confidential contract. If your freight moves under a contract with the carrier, STB rate-reasonableness jurisdiction generally does not apply and contractual remedies or arbitration govern the dispute instead.

The agency's rate oversight exists within a deregulated framework established by the Staggers Rail Act of 1980. Staggers gave carriers significant pricing freedom but preserved regulatory oversight for captive shippers—those with no practical alternative to a single railroad. The STB uses market dominance as the threshold test: if the railroad lacks market dominance over the specific traffic at issue, the agency will not adjudicate the rate's reasonableness on the merits.

sections.heading: When to File a Rate Complaint
sections.content:
A rate complaint is appropriate when you are captive to a single railroad, have no practical truck or barge alternative, and believe the rates charged substantially exceed what would prevail in a competitive market. The STB typically measures "substantially" against a revenue-to-variable-cost ratio: rates above 180% R/VC are presumed subject to review, though proving market dominance and winning on the merits are separate hurdles.

Before filing, conduct a frank assessment of your competitive position. Document why truck or water alternatives are not commercially viable—distance, infrastructure gaps, transit time requirements, or weight restrictions can all factor in. Shippers who cannot clearly articulate their captive status often fail the market dominance screen before the merits of their rate challenge are ever reached.

Timing matters because rate complaints are expensive and slow. Many shippers exhaust commercial negotiations first, then pursue informal STB processes, and reserve formal litigation as a last resort. If volumes are low or the rate dispute involves only a modest dollar amount, the cost of formal proceedings will almost certainly exceed any recovery. The general rule of thumb in the industry is that formal STB rate cases only pencil out when annual freight spend on the challenged traffic exceeds several million dollars.

Also consider the two-year statute of limitations. The STB will not award reparations for overcharges that occurred more than two years before the complaint is filed. Waiting too long while pursuing informal remedies can forfeit your right to recover historical overpayments.

sections.heading: Preparing Your Case
sections.content:
Preparation is the most labor-intensive phase. You will need to reconstruct your entire transportation cost picture—every waybill, every invoice, every fuel surcharge assessed—going back at least two years. This data forms the basis for calculating alleged overcharges and also feeds the standalone cost model if you pursue a full rate-reasonableness case.

Engage experienced rail transportation counsel and an economic consultant familiar with railroad costing. The standalone cost (SAC) methodology requires building a hypothetical efficient railroad sized to serve only your traffic. That model demands detailed knowledge of railroad operations, track geometry, locomotive requirements, crew costs, and capital cost of money. Very few law firms and consulting shops have genuine expertise here; vetting credentials carefully before retaining anyone is time well spent.

Gather all tariff publications, any prior rate negotiations, correspondence with the railroad's pricing department, and records of any service alternatives you explored and rejected. The STB expects shippers to have genuinely attempted to negotiate and to have assessed alternatives rigorously. Gaps in this record weaken the market dominance showing.

If you are a smaller shipper, consider whether joining a coalition with other shippers on the same corridor or traffic lane makes sense. Shared discovery, shared expert costs, and pooled legal resources can make a case economically viable that would otherwise be prohibitive for a single party.

sections.heading: The Filing Process
sections.content:
Formal rate complaints are filed electronically through the STB's e-filing system. The complaint must identify the complainant, the respondent railroad, the specific rates challenged, the traffic lanes at issue, and the relief requested—typically a finding that the rate is unreasonable and an award of reparations for past overcharges plus prospective rate relief.

The STB requires complainants to pay a filing fee, currently several hundred dollars, at the time of submission. After docketing, the railroad has 20 days to answer, though extensions are routinely granted. The agency then issues a procedural schedule governing discovery, expert disclosures, and briefing. Full evidentiary proceedings—called Simplified Standards or stand-alone cost cases depending on the complexity—can take two to four years from filing to a final decision.

For smaller cases the STB offers a Three-Benchmark methodology that compares rates on similar traffic elsewhere in the rail system, avoiding the full SAC analysis. This is substantially cheaper to litigate but is only available when the movements in question are genuinely comparable to benchmarking traffic. The agency also offers a Final Offer Rate Review (FORR) process, a newer mechanism where both sides submit a single proposed rate and the STB picks one—creating pressure to be reasonable.

All filings, decisions, and correspondence in open dockets are publicly available on the STB's website. Monitoring competing and analogous dockets gives your counsel useful intelligence about current evidentiary standards and the agency's current disposition on contested methodological questions.

sections.heading: The Stand-Alone Cost Methodology
sections.content:
The SAC test is the primary evidentiary standard in full rate-reasonableness proceedings. The theory is straightforward: if the revenue the railroad collects from your traffic exceeds what a hypothetical efficient carrier would need to cover all costs of providing that service—including a reasonable return on investment—the rate is unreasonable.

Building a SAC model requires designing the hypothetical railroad from the ground up. This means specifying track miles, grades, curvature, bridge requirements, yard facilities, locomotive types, car fleets, crew districts, and overhead allocations. The model must be sized to handle your traffic volumes only, and it must represent best current practice in railroad engineering—not necessarily how the incumbent carrier actually operates.

The incumbent railroad will contest virtually every assumption in your SAC model. Common battlegrounds include capital cost of money (the discount rate applied to infrastructure investment), locomotive productivity assumptions, the allocation of common costs across traffic types, and whether specific infrastructure elements are necessary to serve your traffic or represent gold-plating. Expert rebuttal testimony and depositions are standard.

Historically, shippers win SAC cases less than half the time at the STB. The methodology favors technically sophisticated and well-resourced parties. That said, the threat of a credible SAC case has historically prompted railroads to negotiate settlements at more favorable rates, making the litigation process itself a commercial leverage tool even when a final decision is never reached.

sections.heading: Timeline and Costs
sections.content:
Expect a full SAC case to run two to four years from initial filing to a final agency decision, with the possibility of additional years if any party seeks judicial review in the federal courts of appeals. The STB has worked to reduce backlogs and improve case management in recent years, but complex rate cases inherently involve large volumes of economic evidence that take time to develop and contest.

Legal and consulting fees for a full SAC case typically range from $2 million to $10 million or more for a well-contested proceeding. The majority of that cost is expert witness work—the economic consultants who build and defend the SAC model. Simpler proceedings under the Three-Benchmark or FORR mechanisms can be conducted for substantially less, often in the range of $500,000 to $2 million depending on complexity and the extent of discovery disputes.

If you prevail, the STB can award reparations—the difference between what you paid and what a reasonable rate would have been—going back two years from the complaint filing date, plus interest. Prospective rate relief takes the form of a maximum reasonable rate prescription that binds the carrier going forward. The agency does not award attorney's fees to prevailing complainants.

Given the economics, many shippers choose to file and then immediately pursue settlement negotiations in parallel. The existence of a pending docket changes the railroad's negotiating posture in ways that informal discussions alone often do not.

sections.heading: Alternatives to Formal Filing
sections.content:
The STB's Office of Public Assistance, Governmental Affairs, and Compliance (OPAGAC) offers informal dispute resolution services at no charge. Shippers can request that OPAGAC facilitate a conversation with the railroad outside of formal docket proceedings. While the agency has no coercive authority in this context, the process sometimes produces resolution in cases where direct negotiation has stalled, simply because both parties prefer to avoid formal litigation.

The STB also administers a voluntary arbitration program for rate disputes. Arbitration under STB supervision is faster and cheaper than formal litigation, and the arbitrator's decision is binding on both parties. However, both the shipper and the railroad must agree to participate—carriers are not obligated to arbitrate. Recent regulatory reforms have expanded the circumstances under which arbitration is available, and this pathway deserves serious evaluation before committing to formal proceedings.

Some shippers pursue regulatory complaints not to win a final decision but to create commercial leverage. Filing a well-crafted complaint signals seriousness, creates discovery obligations for the railroad, and can prompt a settlement conversation that informal pressure alone could not generate. This tactical use of the process is legitimate and well understood by carrier pricing and legal teams.

Finally, consider whether the dispute might be better addressed through the shipper's congressional representatives. The STB is an independent agency but it responds to congressional oversight. Letters from relevant committee chairs or members to the agency or to the railroad's government affairs team have occasionally broken logjams that formal proceedings could not. This avenue works best when the underlying facts are clear and the perceived inequity is easy to communicate.

title: How to Dispute Demurrage Charges
excerpt: Demurrage charges compensate railroads for car detention beyond allowed free time, but billing errors and disputed circumstances are common. A structured dispute process backed by solid documentation gives shippers the best chance of recovering unjustified charges.

sections.heading: Understanding Demurrage
sections.content:
Demurrage is a per-day charge assessed when a shipper or consignee detains a railcar beyond a contractually specified free period. The purpose is to incentivize rapid car cycling—keeping equipment moving rather than sitting at an origin, destination, or intermediate point. Railroads treat demurrage revenue as a car utilization tool and as compensation for the opportunity cost of cars not in productive service.

Free time allowances vary by railroad, car type, and whether the car is loaded or empty. Typical published tariff allowances range from 24 to 48 hours at origin and 24 to 48 hours at destination, though specific commodity tariffs and contract addenda can modify these figures substantially. The free time clock typically starts when the railroad places the car at the appropriate industry track or interchange point and provides constructive placement notice to the customer.

Understanding precisely when placement and notice occur is the foundation of any demurrage dispute. Railroads often assess charges from the moment a car is constructively placed—meaning it is available for placement at the facility even if the facility is full and the car cannot physically enter. Shippers who are unaware of constructive placement provisions can accumulate substantial charges before they realize a car has been placed.

Demurrage rules are published in each railroad's publicly available tariff. The Association of American Railroads also publishes Circular OT-10, which governs car hire and demurrage standards for interchange traffic. Familiarity with both your specific railroad's tariff and OT-10 is essential to identifying where charges may be disputed.

sections.heading: Common Overcharge Scenarios
sections.content:
The most frequent source of incorrect demurrage charges is miscalculated placement time. If the railroad records a constructive placement at a time when the shipper had not yet received proper notice, or when the facility was physically inaccessible due to a railroad-caused delay, the free time clock should not have started when the railroad claims.

Railroad-caused delays are a particularly important category. If a car is held at a classification yard because of locomotive shortage, crew unavailability, or track maintenance, any days spent in that delay should generally be excluded from the demurrage calculation. Railroads are not supposed to charge detention for periods when the delay is attributable to their own operations, but these credits do not always appear automatically on bills.

Holiday and weekend exemptions are another common source of dispute. Many tariffs and contracts exclude Sundays and certain federal holidays from free time calculations. Billing systems sometimes fail to apply these exclusions correctly, particularly around holidays that fall on irregular dates. Reviewing the free time clock day by day against a calendar is tedious but often reveals errors.

Overage charges on cars that were actually released on time but for which the railroad did not properly record the release are also common. If your team has documentation—a release receipt, a signed gate log, a timestamped RFID record—showing a car left your facility before the assessed charge period, that documentation is typically dispositive if properly submitted to the railroad's billing team.

Finally, watch for charges on cars that were misrouted or delivered to the wrong facility by the railroad. A car delivered to the wrong consignee or the wrong industry track creates a situation where the shipper is being charged for detention they did not cause and could not have prevented.

sections.heading: Documentation Needed
sections.content:
Effective demurrage disputes are won with contemporaneous documentation gathered at the time of car movements, not reconstructed after the fact from memory. Establish systems to collect and preserve the following records as a routine matter, before any dispute arises.

Gate logs and car movement records are the core. Every car that enters or leaves your facility should be logged with the date, time, car initial and number, and the name or badge number of the person recording the movement. If your facility has RFID readers, AEI (Automatic Equipment Identification) data provides automated timestamps that are difficult for the railroad to dispute.

Railroad notification records are equally important. Preserve every constructive placement notice you receive—date, time, car number, and the method of notification (EDI, email, phone, online portal). If you believe a placement notice was not properly received, document that at the time, not months later when a bill arrives.

For delay credits, document any events that delayed your ability to move cars: railroad embargoes, bad order notifications from the carrier, track outages at the interchange, or weather events that the carrier acknowledged. Correspondence with your railroad account manager acknowledging delays is particularly valuable.

For contested release times, preserve any signed documentation from the railroad's local agent, outbound switching records, or interchange receipts that establish when control of the car returned to the railroad. Bills of lading, though useful for establishing the shipment context, do not by themselves establish when a car was physically released.

sections.heading: Step-by-Step Dispute Process
sections.content:
Start by obtaining the detailed bill from the railroad's freight billing department. The summary invoice showing a total charge is insufficient for dispute purposes—you need the underlying car-by-car detail showing the date of placement, the end of free time, the number of days charged, and the daily rate applied. Most railroads will provide this detail on request; some make it available through online customer portals.

For each car on the bill, reconcile the railroad's placement date and time against your internal gate records and any notices you received. Flag every discrepancy, however small. Then categorize disputed charges by dispute type: railroad-caused delay, improper placement timing, holiday or weekend exclusion error, disputed release time, or wrong facility delivery.

Prepare a written dispute letter addressed to the railroad's freight billing or credit department. The letter should identify the invoice number and date, list each disputed car by initial and number, state the specific reason for the dispute, cite the relevant tariff provision or contract language, and attach supporting documentation. Be precise about the dollar amount in dispute.

Most railroads have a formal dispute window—typically 60 to 180 days from the invoice date—after which disputes may be time-barred. Submit within this window even if your documentation is incomplete. You can supplement later, but missing the window can waive your rights entirely. Keep a written record of the submission date and request written acknowledgment from the railroad.

Follow up on the dispute in writing at regular intervals. If the railroad denies the dispute, request a written explanation citing the specific provision under which the charge is upheld. That explanation becomes the basis for escalation if needed. Do not let disputes languish with a verbal "we're looking into it" from a railroad account representative.

sections.heading: Escalation to the STB
sections.content:
If the railroad denies your dispute and you believe the denial is incorrect, the Surface Transportation Board has jurisdiction over demurrage charges imposed by common carriers. A formal complaint to the STB is available as a remedy, though the economics need to make sense—agency proceedings take time and carry costs.

The STB issued new demurrage and accessorial rules in 2020 (Demurrage Liability, EP 707) that strengthened shipper protections. Under these rules, railroads must provide clear notice of demurrage charges, must make billing records available to customers upon request, and may not assess demurrage charges in circumstances where the delay is attributable to the railroad. If your dispute involves facts that implicate these rules, cite EP 707 specifically in your escalation correspondence.

Before filing a formal complaint, consider requesting informal dispute resolution through the STB's OPAGAC office. This is a low-cost first step that occasionally produces resolution without formal proceedings. OPAGAC staff will contact the railroad and attempt to facilitate a solution. The process has no coercive power, but railroads generally take OPAGAC inquiries seriously because they prefer to avoid formal dockets.

For amounts that justify formal proceedings, a complaint docket moves faster for demurrage cases than for rate-reasonableness cases because the factual record is more contained. Demurrage disputes turn primarily on documentary evidence rather than complex economic modeling, which compresses the timeline somewhat compared to full SAC proceedings.

sections.heading: Best Practices for Prevention
sections.content:
Prevention is far more cost-effective than dispute. The most important structural change most shippers can make is implementing a real-time car tracking and alert system tied directly to their gate operations. When your team knows a car has been constructively placed the moment it happens, they can act on it rather than discover it weeks later on a bill.

Negotiate demurrage terms proactively during contract renewals. Extended free time, holiday exclusions, railroad-delay credits, and caps on daily rates are all negotiable elements. Shippers with significant volumes have meaningful leverage; use it. Even modest improvements in free time allowances can generate large savings over a year's worth of car movements.

Train operations staff on demurrage mechanics. Many facilities are managed by people who understand the physical railroad operation but are unaware of how charges accrue. A brief training on what triggers the free time clock, how constructive placement works, and what records to keep can change behavior in ways that meaningfully reduce charges.

Conduct periodic audits of demurrage invoices against your internal car movement records. Hire a freight audit firm if internal resources are limited—most operate on a contingency basis and recover a portion of any amounts they identify. Regular audits also create a historical record that is useful if a pattern of billing errors becomes the basis for a more formal complaint.

title: How to Get Your Facility Rail-Served
excerpt: Connecting a facility directly to the rail network requires coordination with a railroad, local permitting authorities, and often significant capital investment. A methodical feasibility and planning process determines whether the economics justify the effort.

sections.heading: Benefits of Rail Service
sections.content:
Direct rail service offers shippers access to the lowest per-ton-mile freight cost mode available for most bulk and semi-bulk commodities. For facilities moving high volumes of heavy goods—chemicals, fertilizers, aggregates, paper, grain, steel—rail can reduce transportation costs by 30% to 70% compared to truckload, depending on the commodity, distance, and truck rate environment. Those savings compound over years and can justify substantial upfront capital.

Beyond cost, rail provides access to markets that truck service cannot economically reach. A facility connected to a Class I railroad has theoretical access to more than 140,000 miles of track and can reach virtually any industrial point in North America without a truck transload. That geographic reach has strategic value independent of the per-shipment economics.

Rail also allows inventory consolidation. Rather than managing frequent, smaller truck deliveries, a rail-served facility can receive or ship in unit-train or multi-car blocks that reduce handling frequency and enable better inventory management. For manufacturers with large raw material requirements, receiving in 50- to 100-car blocks can dramatically reduce the complexity of inbound logistics.

Environmental and safety considerations are increasingly relevant. Rail moves a ton of freight roughly three to four times more fuel-efficiently than truck on a per-mile basis, which translates to lower greenhouse gas intensity. For companies with scope 3 emissions reduction targets, shifting freight from truck to rail is one of the highest-leverage interventions available in the supply chain.

sections.heading: Evaluating Feasibility
sections.content:
The first feasibility question is proximity. How close is your facility to the nearest active rail line, and who owns it? Use publicly available railroad maps—the STB publishes a national rail network map, and individual railroads publish their own system maps—to identify what lines are within a reasonable distance. In general, a spur length of under one mile is much easier to justify economically than one requiring several miles of new track construction.

Volume is the critical economic variable. Railroads typically want to see a minimum of one to three cars per week before they will seriously engage on a new spur connection, and the economic returns to the shipper improve dramatically as volume increases toward unit-train levels. Calculate your expected annual volume in carloads, your current truck spend on that traffic, and the differential—that spread needs to be large enough to amortize the spur construction cost over a reasonable period.

Site geometry matters as much as volume. A rail spur requires a minimum track curvature radius (typically 400 feet for standard industrial spurs, sometimes tighter with engineering approval), adequate grade (generally no more than 2% for loading tracks), and sufficient straight track length at the loading or unloading position to accommodate the cars you intend to use. Some facilities are physically unsuited to rail connection regardless of volume; a licensed track engineer's initial assessment will tell you quickly.

Permitting complexity at the local level is sometimes the deciding factor. Rail spurs cross roads, may require easements through third-party property, and trigger environmental review in sensitive areas. A desk study of the likely permitting path—consulting with local planning staff before committing capital to engineering—can reveal fatal flaws early when they are cheap to discover rather than late when they are not.

sections.heading: Working with the Railroad
sections.content:
Initial contact with the railroad should go through the railroad's Industrial Development department, sometimes called the Economic Development group. These teams are specifically charged with attracting new freight business and facilitating facility connections. They are generally easier to work with than the railroad's operating or commercial groups and have the most direct interest in seeing new spurs completed.

Prepare a brief for your initial railroad meeting that covers your facility location (with a site map), annual volume projections in carloads, commodity type and car type requirements, your anticipated origin or destination points for traffic, and your preferred service frequency. The railroad will use this information to conduct an internal feasibility assessment and estimate its cost to connect your facility from the mainline or nearest branch.

The railroad's cost estimate covers the connection to its system—the switch and any track improvements on its property required to accommodate your traffic. This is separate from the cost of the spur on your property. Railroads sometimes contribute to spur construction costs for high-volume shippers, offer favorable joint facility arrangements, or provide locomotives and crew for switching under a switching agreement. All of these terms are negotiable.

Be aware that the railroad will want to execute an industry track agreement (sometimes called a sidetrack agreement) before any construction begins. This contract governs the physical connection between your spur and the railroad's mainline, establishes operating rights and responsibilities, specifies maintenance obligations, and addresses liability. Have rail transportation counsel review this agreement carefully—the standard railroad form is heavily one-sided, and many provisions are negotiable with pushback.

sections.heading: Construction and Permitting
sections.content:
Once the railroad approves the connection concept and the sidetrack agreement is executed, construction of the on-property spur is typically the shipper's responsibility and expense. Engage a licensed railroad track contractor with experience in Class I connections—these contractors understand the railroad's engineering standards and inspection requirements, which differ from general civil construction.

The permitting path typically involves local land use approval, any required at-grade crossing permits from state transportation departments, environmental permits if grading or drainage work is significant, and possibly a federal crossing permit if the spur crosses a navigable waterway. In urban and suburban areas, public hearings may be required. Build at least six months of permitting time into your project schedule, and plan for longer in jurisdictions with complex review processes.

The railroad will conduct engineering review and inspection at multiple stages: track geometry, ballast depth, tie condition, and connection hardware must all meet its engineering standards before the railroad will permit cars to enter your facility. Budget for at least two railroad inspections—one mid-construction and one before handoff—and plan for punch-list items to be identified at each inspection.

Construction costs for an industrial spur vary widely based on length, site conditions, and geographic region. A rough planning figure of $1 million to $2 million per mile of new track construction is often cited, but this can be much higher in areas with difficult terrain, expensive real estate, or high labor costs. Get multiple contractor bids with detailed scope specifications before committing to a budget.

sections.heading: Costs and Timeline
sections.content:
Total project timelines from initial feasibility to first car typically range from 18 months to four years, depending on permitting complexity, construction season constraints, and railroad review timelines. Plan conservatively and build schedule contingency—virtually every industrial spur project experiences at least one significant delay in the permitting or construction phases.

Beyond construction, factor in ongoing maintenance costs. Industry track maintenance is the spur owner's responsibility under virtually all sidetrack agreements. Annual maintenance costs for an industrial spur—including annual track inspection by a licensed inspector, periodic resurfacing, tie replacement programs, and vegetation control—typically run $20,000 to $100,000 per year depending on track length, use frequency, and geographic climate.

Switching costs are a recurring operational expense that shippers sometimes overlook in initial financial modeling. If the railroad provides local switching to spot and pull cars, it charges a switching fee per car or per switch movement. On low-volume spurs the railroad may only switch a few times per week, creating car detention risk. On high-volume facilities you may need to negotiate dedicated switching windows or a host switching agreement where the railroad provides specified service times.

Financing options for industrial spur construction include direct capital expenditure, equipment financing (if the spur is classified as a capital asset), and in some cases state or federal economic development grants. Several states operate industrial rail access programs that provide grants or low-interest loans to encourage new rail connections. The FRA's Consolidated Rail Infrastructure and Safety Improvements (CRISI) program also funds rail-related infrastructure, though competition for those funds is intense.

sections.heading: Operations Startup
sections.content:
Before your first commercial car moves, establish your operating procedures in detail. Identify who on your staff is responsible for monitoring car placements, releasing cars, and communicating with the railroad's local customer service team. Designate a primary contact at the railroad and exchange direct contact information—good operational relationships at the local level prevent many problems that would otherwise escalate to billing disputes.

Establish your demurrage monitoring process from day one. Implement a car tracking system that logs every car placement and release with timestamps. Even a simple spreadsheet maintained by a dedicated person is better than nothing; a commercial car tracking service that integrates with railroad EDI feeds is better still. The cost of demurrage on an unmonitored spur can easily dwarf the savings rail service was supposed to deliver.

Conduct a tabletop exercise with operations staff before the first car arrives, walking through the process from placement notification to unloading to car release. Identify what could go wrong—slow unloading, equipment failures, weekend staffing gaps—and establish procedures for each scenario. The cost of this preparation is trivial compared to the cost of discovering process gaps through actual overcharges.

Plan for a ramp-up period of three to six months before your operation reaches steady-state efficiency. New spur operations typically have higher demurrage charges, more operational errors, and more communication breakdowns during the early months than after the team has developed familiarity with the rhythm of rail operations. Set expectations with leadership accordingly and use the ramp-up period as a learning opportunity rather than a performance measurement period.

title: Understanding Railroad Tariffs and Rate Structures
excerpt: Railroad tariffs establish the legal basis for freight rates and contain complex pricing structures that vary by commodity, distance, car type, and volume. Knowing how to read and interpret these documents is essential for effective freight cost management.

sections.heading: What Is a Railroad Tariff
sections.content:
A railroad tariff is a legally binding schedule of freight charges, rules, and terms published by a rail carrier and made available to the shipping public. Under federal law, railroads must publish tariffs for their common-carrier services—those offered to any shipper without discrimination—and must charge only the published rate for covered traffic. This publication requirement exists to ensure shippers can determine in advance what they will pay.

Tariffs are filed electronically and made available through the railroad's public website or tariff publishing agent. Each major railroad publishes hundreds of tariffs covering different commodities, service types, and traffic lanes. A tariff document is identified by a name, a number, and an issue date. When a tariff is amended, the amended version supersedes the prior version, and the effective dates of each amendment are recorded in the tariff's history pages.

The legal significance of tariffs is considerable. The filed-rate doctrine holds that the rate in the applicable tariff at the time of shipment is the rate that governs, regardless of what any railroad representative may have quoted verbally. This doctrine protects the integrity of the tariff system but can produce harsh results when a shipper acts on a misquoted rate. Always verify rates by obtaining the tariff publication reference—the specific tariff name, item number, and effective date—in writing before tendering freight.

Not all railroad freight moves under tariff rates. Traffic governed by confidential rate contracts is exempt from tariff requirements; the contract itself is the governing document. Traffic under exempt commodity categories established by the STB moves outside the tariff system entirely. Understanding which legal framework governs your specific traffic type is the prerequisite to any rate analysis.

sections.heading: Types of Rate Structures
sections.content:
Class rates are the most basic rate structure, applying a standard rate to a commodity classification defined in the Uniform Freight Classification (UFC) or the National Motor Freight Classification (NMFC) system. Class rates are relatively rare in modern railroad pricing, having been largely displaced by commodity-specific rates, but they still apply to unusual freight not covered by a specific commodity tariff.

Commodity rates are the dominant rate type in railroad tariffs. These rates are published for specific commodities—often defined by STCC (Standard Transportation Commodity Code)—moving between specific origins and destinations or within geographic zones. Commodity rates typically include minimum car size, loading requirements, and any applicable restrictions on packaging or handling. They are almost always lower than class rates for the same freight.

Unit-train and multi-car rates represent volume pricing. Shippers who can tender freight in blocks of typically 50 to 110 cars can access substantially reduced per-car rates that reflect the railroad's operating efficiency advantage when handling high-volume, point-to-point movements. These rates often include service guarantees—specified transit times and guaranteed availability—alongside the pricing benefit.

Incentive rates are volume-based pricing structures that reward shippers for committing to or achieving threshold annual volumes. They may take the form of tiered rates that decrease as cumulative annual volume rises, or rebate programs that pay back a portion of charges when volume commitments are met. Incentive rate structures require careful financial modeling because the structure can create awkward incentives around year-end that influence transportation decisions inappropriately.

sections.heading: Public vs. Contract Rates
sections.content:
Public tariff rates are available to any shipper for any qualifying shipment, without prior negotiation or commitment. Because they are available on demand, they typically represent the ceiling on pricing rather than the norm—most large shippers do not pay public tariff rates for routine traffic. Public rates serve as a backstop for occasional or emergency shipments, for shippers whose volumes do not justify contract negotiations, and as a benchmark against which contract rates can be measured.

Contract rates are confidential agreements between a shipper and a carrier. The Staggers Rail Act authorized rail rate contracts, breaking from the prior common-carrier-only regime, and they have become the dominant pricing vehicle for large industrial shippers. Contracts typically include volume commitments, rate levels (often tied to index adjustments), service standards, and terms for car supply. In exchange for rate certainty and potentially lower rates, the shipper accepts volume commitment risk.

The trade-off between contract and tariff is a recurring strategic decision. A long-term contract locks in favorable rates but exposes the shipper to volume shortfall penalties if business conditions change. Public tariff rates offer flexibility but at higher cost and without service guarantees. Many sophisticated shippers maintain a portfolio approach—contracting the predictable core of their traffic while keeping some volume on tariff for flexibility.

Contracts are not filed publicly and are not available for STB review under normal circumstances, though the agency can access contract information under specific circumstances related to rate complaints or competitive access proceedings. This confidentiality means shippers generally cannot see what competitors are paying, which is one reason industry benchmarking surveys and freight audit data are commercially valuable.

sections.heading: How to Read a Tariff
sections.content:
Railroad tariff documents have a standardized structure that can initially seem opaque but follows consistent conventions once learned. The front matter identifies the issuing carrier, the tariff number, the effective date, and any supplements or amendments that modify the base document. Read this section carefully—an outdated tariff print can be dangerous if rates have since changed.

The rules section of the tariff precedes the rate tables and governs how the rates are applied. Rules establish minimum and maximum car weights, define what counts as an acceptable shipment, specify loading and unloading responsibilities, address liability limitations, and handle special circumstances like diversion, reconsignment, and transit arrangements. Skipping the rules section to get directly to the rate tables is a common mistake that leads to disputes when a rule that affects your shipment is discovered only after the fact.

Rate tables in commodity tariffs are typically organized by origin-destination pair or by geographic zone, with rates expressed per hundredweight (CWT), per net ton, or per car. When a rate table references a geographic zone, there will be a separate zone definition section that lists every station or area code included in each zone. Verifying that your specific origin and destination are correctly included in the referenced zones prevents the most common tariff misapplication errors.

Applicable rates are often built from multiple tariff items stacked together: a base rate, a fuel surcharge factor, any applicable accessorial charges, and potentially an incentive adjustment. The total rate you actually pay is the sum of all applicable items, not just the rate shown in the commodity rate table. When seeking a quote, ask the railroad to provide the all-in rate inclusive of all applicable surcharges and accessorials for a specific date, rather than assembling the components yourself.

sections.heading: Fuel Surcharges
sections.content:
Fuel surcharges have been a standard component of railroad freight pricing since their introduction in the early 2000s in response to diesel price volatility. They are assessed as a percentage of the base rate or as a flat per-car or per-mile charge, and they adjust on a monthly or weekly basis tied to a published diesel price index—most commonly the US Department of Energy's weekly retail on-highway diesel price.

The mechanics of fuel surcharge calculation vary by railroad and even by tariff. Some carriers use a mileage-based formula that assigns a surcharge percentage per 1,000 miles of haul. Others apply a flat percentage to the base rate regardless of distance. These structural differences matter because the two approaches produce different results for long versus short hauls. A shipper with a mix of haul lengths will want to model the actual surcharge impact rather than assuming a simple percentage applies uniformly.

Fuel surcharges are fully negotiable in contract settings. Some contracts cap the surcharge percentage, exclude it from the base rate for volume commitment calculations, or tie it to an alternative index the shipper believes better represents actual fuel costs. In periods of high diesel prices, fuel surcharges can represent 20% to 30% of total freight cost, making these contract provisions economically significant.

When comparing railroad rates to truck or other modal alternatives, always compare all-in costs including fuel surcharges on both sides. Truck fuel surcharges and rail fuel surcharges use different index bases and calculation methodologies, so a rate comparison that looks at base rates only will mislead the modal choice analysis.

sections.heading: Negotiation Tips
sections.content:
Enter rate negotiations with a complete understanding of your freight profile—annual volume by lane, commodity, car type, season, and any growth plans. Railroads price based on network economics, and the more precisely you can describe your traffic, the better you can engage on the specific factors that drive the railroad's cost and revenue model for your shipments.

Know your alternatives. Even partial alternatives—truck for shorter lanes, barge where waterways are accessible, an interchange to a competing railroad at a junction point—create negotiating leverage. Railroads price more aggressively for traffic they fear losing to another mode. If you have genuinely captive traffic with no alternatives, acknowledge that reality internally, but also recognize that some carriers negotiate more competitively than their market position strictly requires in order to maintain long-term customer relationships.

Time your negotiations strategically. Railroads typically finalize their commercial plans for the following year in the fall, meaning early-to-mid fall is when account managers have the most flexibility and authority to offer favorable terms. Approaching a renewal in the first quarter of the contract year, when the carrier's commercial calendar is already set, typically produces worse outcomes.

Consider engaging a freight consultant or transportation attorney for significant rate negotiations. The railroad's pricing team negotiates these agreements daily; most shipper-side procurement teams do so infrequently. The expertise gap is real, and a consultant who understands railroad cost structures, knows current market rates, and has relationships with carrier pricing staff can meaningfully improve outcomes. Fee structures that align the consultant's compensation with savings generated keep incentives properly aligned.

title: How to Choose a Transload Provider
excerpt: Transloading extends rail service to facilities that are not rail-served by transferring freight between rail cars and trucks at an intermediate terminal. Selecting the right transload partner requires evaluating location, commodity capability, operational performance, and contractual protections.

sections.heading: What Is Transloading
sections.content:
Transloading is the process of transferring freight from one transportation mode to another at an intermediate facility, without the freight having reached its final destination. In the rail context, transloading most commonly refers to unloading cargo from railcars and reloading it into trucks for the final mile, or the reverse—consolidating truck shipments into railcars for the long-haul portion of a journey.

A transload facility is a purpose-built or purpose-converted site that combines rail track access with truck access, storage, and the physical handling equipment needed for a specific commodity type. Facilities range from simple warehouse operations with a siding for boxcar loading to sophisticated terminals handling liquids, bulk materials, or specialized project cargo with dedicated pumping stations, conveyor systems, or crane equipment.

Transloading is not to be confused with cross-docking, which typically refers to truck-to-truck transfer with minimal storage, or with intermodal operations, which involve containers or trailers moving on flatcars without the freight being disturbed. In transloading, the freight itself changes containers—it is physically moved from the originating container or car into a new one for the next mode.

The economics of transloading rest on the premise that the cost savings from using rail for the long-haul portion of a journey, where rail's ton-mile efficiency advantage is greatest, exceed the added cost of the transload handling operation. This calculation is favorable for high-density, low-value commodities over long distances and becomes less favorable for time-sensitive, high-value, or fragile goods where transit time and handling risk weigh heavily.

sections.heading: When to Transload vs. Direct Rail
sections.content:
Direct rail service—moving freight by rail from a rail-served origin directly to a rail-served destination—is operationally simpler and usually lower cost per unit when both facilities are rail-served. If your facility and your customer's facility both have active spurs on the same railroad or connected railroads, direct rail should be the default option and transloading should be considered only if direct rail cannot satisfy service requirements.

Transloading becomes the preferred option when one or both endpoints lack rail access, when the rail-served alternative is significantly distant from the actual freight origin or destination, or when the shipment size does not justify a direct car movement but could be consolidated economically at a transload point. It is also useful when the commodity changes form between origin and destination—for example, when a bulk railcar load is repackaged into smaller units at the transload facility for retail distribution.

Service time is often the deciding factor in the transload versus direct rail decision. Direct rail transit times are often measured in days to a week or more for long-haul movements, and the variability can be substantial. Adding a transload step typically adds one to three days to total transit and introduces additional variability at the transload facility. For customers with tight delivery windows or just-in-time receiving operations, this additional transit variability may be unacceptable even if the cost economics favor transloading.

Some shippers use transloading tactically—switching between direct truck, transload rail, and direct rail depending on rate market conditions, seasonal volume patterns, or service priorities. This flexibility requires having relationships with transload providers already established and rates pre-negotiated so that the switch can be made quickly without re-tendering to new providers.

sections.heading: Key Evaluation Criteria
sections.content:
Location is the first screening criterion. A transload facility must be positioned so that the truck legs—from your origin to the transload facility and from the transload facility to your customer—are short enough to be cost-effective. In general, truck legs beyond 150 to 200 miles at either end of the move begin to erode the savings from the rail portion. Map the geographic relationship between your origins, the candidate transload facilities, and your destinations before evaluating any other factor.

Commodity-specific capability is non-negotiable. Handling bulk chemicals requires different certifications, containment systems, and trained personnel than handling bagged agricultural products or steel coils. Verify that the transload facility you are considering has specific experience with your commodity, the appropriate permits (EPA, DOT, state environmental), and the mechanical equipment matched to your product. A general-purpose warehouse that claims it can handle your commodity is very different from a specialist that has processed it for years.

Railroad connectivity determines which traffic lanes are accessible. A transload facility served by a single short line connecting to one Class I railroad is useful for lanes on that railroad's system. A facility with multiple railroad connections, or one positioned at an interchange between two Class I carriers, provides access to more of the national network and offers leverage in rate negotiations. Ask which railroads serve the facility and what service frequency each offers.

Capacity—both storage and throughput—must be sized to your peak requirements, not your average. A transload facility that can handle your average weekly volume but cannot accommodate a surge during peak season will fail you precisely when reliable service matters most. Understand the facility's maximum daily and weekly throughput for your commodity, what its current utilization is, and how it manages capacity allocation among competing customers during peak periods.

sections.heading: Site Visit Checklist
sections.content:
A site visit before awarding business is essential. A transload facility is a physical operation, and its condition, organization, and management culture are visible in ways that documents and presentations cannot fully convey. Plan to spend at least half a day at any facility you are seriously considering.

Observe the track condition inside the facility. Look for proper ballast, tie condition, and whether the track appears to be maintained proactively or only when problems arise. Ask when the most recent track inspection was conducted and request a copy of the inspection report. Track in poor condition is a safety risk and an operational reliability risk—derailments at transload facilities, though uncommon, do occur and can shut a facility down for weeks.

Assess the material handling equipment. Ask about the age of each piece of major equipment—cranes, forklifts, conveyor systems, pumping equipment—and the maintenance program for each. Request maintenance records. Equipment that is frequently out of service creates bottlenecks that will delay your freight. Ask what backup equipment is available if a primary piece of equipment fails.

Talk to operations staff, not just management. The people who will actually be handling your freight—the forklift operators, the car riders, the scale operators—have a ground-level perspective on facility reliability and management practices that is different from and complementary to what you hear in the management presentation. Observe how staff members interact with management during the tour; signs of poor morale or communication dysfunction are worth noting.

Review the facility's safety record. Request their OSHA 300 log for the past three years, their DOT inspection history if they handle regulated materials, and the results of any third-party safety audits conducted on behalf of other customers. A facility with a poor safety record is a liability risk for your business as well as for its own people.

sections.heading: Contract Negotiation
sections.content:
Transload agreements should be in writing and should cover the full scope of the commercial relationship: services to be provided, pricing, service standards, liability allocation, insurance requirements, term and termination provisions, and dispute resolution. Relying on a handshake or an exchange of emails for a significant transload relationship is a recipe for conflict when problems arise.

Service standards should be specific and measurable. Define unloading and loading cycle times, storage dwell time limits, shipment accuracy requirements, and notification protocols for delays or exceptions. Establish reporting requirements—what data the provider will give you, how often, and in what format. A service agreement that says only "provider will perform transload services in a professional manner" provides no basis for measuring performance or enforcing accountability.

Liability provisions are often heavily negotiated. The transload provider will want to cap its liability at a low multiple of its service fee; you will want the provider to be fully responsible for any damage to your freight while in its care, custody, and control. Standard industry practice is for the provider to carry cargo legal liability insurance, and you should be named as an additional insured on that policy. Verify that the insurance is actually in force—request certificates of insurance directly from the carrier, not from the transload provider.

Termination provisions should give you flexibility without creating an unreasonable exit barrier. Evergreen contracts that automatically renew for long terms without a reasonable termination right are dangerous if the provider's performance deteriorates. Negotiate a termination for convenience clause with a reasonable notice period—typically 60 to 90 days—that does not require you to demonstrate a material breach before you can exit the relationship.

sections.heading: Ongoing Performance Management
sections.content:
Establishing the relationship well is only the beginning; ongoing performance management determines whether the relationship delivers consistent value. Implement a monthly performance review process that measures the provider against the service standards in your contract. Share the results with the provider's management team and require written response to any metrics that miss target.

Visit the facility in person at least once or twice per year, in addition to any audits or inspections triggered by performance problems. Relationships maintained only through electronic dashboards and monthly calls tend to drift; periodic in-person presence signals the importance of the relationship, builds personal connections with operations staff, and gives you direct visibility into any changes in the facility's condition or management.

Benchmark your transload costs annually against current market rates. Transload pricing is not regulated and varies with real estate markets, labor costs, and competitive dynamics. A rate that was competitive when you signed your contract three years ago may or may not be competitive today. Knowing the market prevents you from overpaying out of inertia and provides factual grounding for rate renewal negotiations.

Maintain a contingency plan. Identify one or two backup transload facilities that could handle your freight on short notice if your primary provider has a significant outage. Establishing a minimal level of relationship with backup providers—even if only introducing yourself and confirming their capability—reduces your recovery time if the primary relationship fails. Single-source dependency on a transload provider carries operational risk that is disproportionate to the cost of maintaining an alternative.

title: Ordering and Managing Private Railcars
excerpt: Private railcar ownership or leasing gives shippers control over equipment availability, car specifications, and fleet utilization that railroad-furnished equipment cannot provide. Building and managing a private fleet requires decisions across procurement, specification, maintenance, and network planning.

sections.heading: Buy vs. Lease Decision
sections.content:
The fundamental private car decision is whether to own the equipment outright or lease it from a car owner such as a leasing company, a financial institution, or a railroad. Each structure has distinct financial, operational, and strategic characteristics that should be evaluated against your specific transportation and balance sheet objectives.

Ownership provides the maximum operational control and, over a long holding period, the lowest total cost if utilization is high. Railcar asset lives extend to 40 or 50 years with proper maintenance, meaning an owned fleet can serve multiple economic cycles. Ownership also creates an asset that can be sold or subleased if your transportation needs change, though liquidity for used railcars varies considerably by car type. Ownership requires upfront capital—new car orders typically require deposits and progress payments during construction—and places residual value risk entirely on the owner.

Leasing transfers residual value risk to the lessor and preserves capital for other uses. Operating leases keep the asset off your balance sheet (under pre-FASB-842 accounting rules; current rules require most lease obligations to be recognized), which mattered historically for debt covenant management. Short-term leases—typically one to three years—offer flexibility to adjust fleet size with changing business needs but at a premium rate compared to long-term leases or ownership. Long-term leases of ten or more years often approach ownership economics without the upfront capital commitment.

Many sophisticated private car owners use a portfolio approach: owning a core fleet sized to their minimum baseload requirements, leasing additional cars on short-term contracts to handle volume peaks and fleet type experimentation, and using railroad-furnished equipment as a backstop of last resort. This structure balances cost efficiency for the core volume with flexibility for variability.

sections.heading: Car Specifications
sections.content:
Specifying a railcar correctly for your commodity is a specialized engineering and commercial exercise. An incorrectly specified car creates operational problems—poor loading efficiency, excessive tare weight, incompatibility with customer unloading equipment—that impose costs every cycle for the life of the car. Spend the time to get specifications right before placing an order.

The starting point is your commodity's physical characteristics: bulk density, angle of repose (for gravity-unloaded hoppers), corrosivity, flammability, regulatory classification, and any special handling requirements. These properties determine the appropriate car type—covered hopper, tank car, gondola, boxcar, flatcar, or specialty car—and set constraints on materials of construction, liner requirements, and unloading mechanisms.

For tank cars, specification decisions include tank capacity, pressure rating, material of construction (carbon steel, stainless steel, or aluminum), heating coils, insulation, the type of bottom outlet (valve size and configuration), and DOT or AAR car class designation. Regulatory requirements for hazardous materials establish minimum standards, but your commodity's specific handling requirements often dictate specifications beyond the minimum. Consult with a tank car engineering firm and your customer's unloading facility before finalizing specifications.

For covered hoppers, key specification decisions include cubic foot capacity, number and type of discharge outlets (gravity versus pneumatic), slope of the hoppers, hatch size and configuration, and whether the car requires a specific coating or lining for product purity or moisture sensitivity. Cubic footage sizing is a critical economic variable—a car that is too small forces more car cycles; a car that is too large relative to your commodity's bulk density runs heavy and may encounter weight restrictions at some facilities.

Design load rating and gross rail load (GRL) are critical infrastructure compatibility parameters. Most North American main lines are rated for 286,000 pounds GRL (286K), but many short lines, branch lines, and industrial tracks operate at lower GRL limits. If any of your regular traffic lanes traverse lower-GRL track, your car specifications must be set to operate within that limit, which constrains payload capacity.

sections.heading: Working with Car Builders
sections.content:
The North American railcar manufacturing industry is concentrated among a small number of major builders: Trinity Industries, Greenbrier Companies, American Railcar Industries (now part of ITE Management), and National Steel Car in Canada. Specialty cars may come from smaller specialized manufacturers. The choice of builder affects delivery time, price, warranty terms, and the long-term parts availability that affects maintenance costs over the car's life.

Soliciting competitive bids from multiple builders is standard practice for orders of meaningful size—typically 50 cars or more. For smaller orders, you may find that one builder is willing to include your order in a pool order with other buyers to achieve production economics, or that you are better served leasing from an existing fleet rather than ordering new. New car lead times typically range from six months to 18 months depending on builder backlog, so plan procurement timelines accordingly.

The order process involves executing a purchase agreement that specifies the car configuration in precise detail, the delivery schedule, the price (typically fixed at order but sometimes with escalation clauses tied to steel indices for orders with long build windows), warranty terms, and acceptance test procedures. Have experienced rail transportation counsel review the purchase agreement—builder standard forms are seller-friendly on liability, warranty limitation, and dispute resolution provisions.

Acceptance testing at the builder's facility before delivery is important for catching specification deviations when they are cheapest to correct. Define acceptance criteria explicitly in the purchase agreement—dimensional tolerances, weight, operational function of all components—and conduct a physical inspection of a representative sample of cars before signing the delivery receipt. Deficiencies discovered post-delivery are harder and more expensive to remedy than those caught at the builder.

sections.heading: Fleet Management Basics
sections.content:
Managing a private railcar fleet requires ongoing visibility into where each car is, what state it is in, and how productively it is cycling. The foundation of fleet management is car location data, which is available through the AAR's Umler system and through commercial tracking services that provide near-real-time position updates from railroad system records.

Car hire is the per-diem charge that accrues when your private car is on a railroad's property beyond your facility. When your car is in transit or sitting in a railroad yard, the car is on the railroad's property and subject to car hire. Car hire rates are established by the AAR and vary by car type and car age. Controlling car hire cost requires minimizing time your cars spend on railroad property—which means efficient loading and unloading at your facilities, prompt car release, and active management of any cars that appear to be stalled or lost in the network.

Car distribution—moving empty cars from where they unloaded to where they need to load next—is often the largest operational challenge in private fleet management. Empty car movements accrue car hire without generating revenue, and the railroad's interest in moving your empty cars efficiently is limited compared to its interest in moving loaded revenue equipment. Establishing clear empty car return instructions in your car marks (the routing instructions embedded in the car's Umler record) and actively monitoring cars that have been released helps minimize unproductive dwell.

Fleet utilization is the key performance metric: what percentage of your cars are productively loaded or in transit at any given time versus sitting empty, in bad order status, or in storage? Healthy private fleet utilization for active traffic typically runs in the 70% to 85% range; utilization below 60% suggests either excess fleet size or operational problems that need diagnosis. Track utilization by car and by month to identify patterns and outliers.

sections.heading: Maintenance Programs
sections.content:
Federal regulations (FRA and DOT) mandate specific inspection and maintenance intervals for freight equipment used in interchange service. At minimum, cars must receive a periodic freight car mechanical inspection (known as a 1033 inspection under FRA rules) at intervals not to exceed five years, or sooner if triggered by an accident, a bad order report, or regulatory revision. Tank cars carrying certain hazardous materials have shorter inspection cycles and additional qualification testing requirements.

As the car owner, you are responsible for the cost of all maintenance, whether performed by your own shop (if you have one), a railroad mechanical facility, or an independent repair facility. Many private car owners without their own maintenance capability contract maintenance to a specialized railcar repair company—firms like American Railcar Leasing, TTX (for flatcars), or regional independents that operate repair facilities at strategic locations on the national network.

Establishing a proactive maintenance program—not just responding to bad orders as they occur—significantly reduces total lifecycle maintenance costs and improves fleet availability. Track maintenance history for each car individually, schedule periodic preventive maintenance around the regulatory inspection cycle, and establish a parts inventory for common wear items (gaskets, valves, outlet fittings, brake components) that can be supplied to repair facilities rather than waiting on parts sourcing.

Tank car qualification is a distinct and regulated maintenance activity for cars carrying hazardous materials. Qualification typically involves internal visual inspection, pressure testing, and for older car designs, thickness testing of the tank shell. These tests must be performed by AAR-certified testing facilities and documented in the car's maintenance record. Non-qualified tank cars cannot be loaded with regulated commodities, so lapse in qualification is a significant operational disruption. Build qualification tracking into your fleet management system with advance alerts for upcoming expiration dates.

sections.heading: When to Expand Your Fleet
sections.content:
Fleet expansion decisions should be driven by a rigorous analysis of utilization data, market forecasts, and the economics of alternative equipment sources. Expanding too early results in excess fleet with high carrying costs; expanding too late results in car shortages that limit your shipping capacity and force reliance on higher-cost railroad-furnished equipment or spot leasing.

The trigger for a fleet expansion analysis is typically sustained utilization above 85% for several consecutive months, combined with evidence of constrained shipping capacity—orders unfilled, customers waiting on railcars, or excessive use of spot-leased equipment. High utilization alone is insufficient if it reflects a temporary seasonal peak that will not persist through the full year.

Model the expansion decision with multiple volume scenarios. Transportation demand is uncertain, and a fleet sized for an optimistic growth forecast will have poor utilization if that forecast does not materialize. Evaluate the expected financial return on fleet expansion across base, upside, and downside scenarios, and establish the conditions under which the expansion remains value-positive. If the economics only work under the most optimistic assumptions, wait for more evidence before committing capital.

Consider the secondhand market before placing a new car order. Used railcars are available through brokers, leasing company remarketing operations, and directly from other shippers who are downsizing or exiting certain traffic lanes. Used cars can be acquired faster and often at lower cost than new construction, though condition inspection and any necessary refurbishment must be factored into the total cost. For non-specialized car types in good condition, the used market often provides attractive value compared to new construction.
